title: 110_hr3193
content: The Act titled "Access to Community Pharmacy Preservation Act of 2007" is about dispensing fees for Medicaid covered outpatient drugs. The "Access to Community Pharmacy Preservation Act of 2007" amends Section 1927(e) of the Social Security Act to include provisions for dispensing fees for Medicaid covered outpatient drugs. States are required to pay a dispensing fee for each covered outpatient drug, with the option to vary the amount based on certain circumstances. A State must establish a dispensing fee of at least $8 per prescription unit for multiple source drugs under the "Access to Community Pharmacy Preservation Act of 2007". The effective date of this amendment is determined by the State legislature session after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 3 amends the Social Security Act to increase pharmacy reimbursement flexibility for states. It allows states to vary payments to pharmacies based on special circumstances. The effective date for these amendments is January 1, 2008. SEC. 4 eliminates the state option to increase the cap amount on individuals' equity asset test for Medicaid long-term care assistance eligibility. Section 1917(f)(1) of the Social Security Act is amended to remove subparagraph (B) and make conforming amendments. The effective date for these changes applies to individuals eligible for medical assistance for nursing facility services or long-term care services based on applications filed after the enactment of this section. Additionally, the SSI asset verification demonstration is extended to Medicaid. The Secretary of Health and Human Services collaborates with the Commissioner of Social Security to use a system for verifying financial eligibility for medical assistance. The system is limited to states where it is used to verify eligibility for benefits under title XVI of the Social Security Act. The Commissioner collaborates with financial institutions to verify eligibility for benefits under title XVI of the Social Security Act. Information obtained may be shared with state agencies administering plans under title XIX.
